title: First Sunday of Lent Liturgy will only be online - Zoom Only
body:
Dear Dignity/New York Community,

After careful consideration, we have decided that our liturgy this Sunday will be held on Zoom only and we will not meet in person.

This decision is based on the current weather advisories, including the Blizzard Warning, expected snow accumulation during the late afternoon and evening hours, dropping temperatures creating icy conditions, and the likelihood of deteriorating travel between 6:00 PM and 8:30 PM. Our priority is the safety of our members and guests, especially those who rely on public transportation or must travel after dark.

Liturgy will begin at our usual time of 6:30 PM Eastern. The Zoom link and worship aid will be sent as usual.

Please help us spread the word by contacting anyone who may not regularly check email or social media. We want to ensure that no one travels unnecessarily.

Thank you for your flexibility and care for one another. We look forward to gathering together virtually.

In community,

[Name]
Dignity/New York Steering Committee

title: Ash Wednesday Service February 18,2026
Important Notice: Zoom-Only Liturgy This Sunday, January 25
body:
Due to the major snowstorm expected to impact the New York City region this Sunday, our liturgy will be held virtually on Zoom only. No one will be present at St. John’s.

Our liturgy will begin at the usual time, 6:30 PM Eastern. A worship aid with full information will be sent in advance.

Please help spread the word to anyone who may not see this announcement.

For everyone’s safety, we encourage you to stay home and stay safe. We hope you will be able to join us on Zoom for liturgy and virtual social time afterward.

title: There is Still Time to Contribute to the Dignity/New York Advent Appeal
body:
November 2025

Dear Members and Friends of Dignity/New York,

As Advent approaches, we look back on another eventful year in the life of our community.  Our inspiring Sunday liturgies, both in person and online, our socials at St. John’s, and our Zoom chats anchor us in weekly worship and support.  Our many other celebrations, informal dinners, theater outings, Pride activities, and social media presence deepen our connections to one another.  Our commitment to equality and inclusion for people of all sexual orientations and genders in the Catholic Church and society is just as strong as ever.

In these difficult times, particularly for the LGBTQIA+ community, we are especially mindful of the Advent promise of justice.  For 53 years, we have been working for justice through countless acts of witness in the streets, in the courts, and through the media. Through our leaders in DignityUSA, our message has now been heard at the highest levels of our church, at the recent Vatican Synod and in a personal meeting with the late Pope Francis.

Needless to say, we could not do all of this without your generous financial support. As you can see from the financial report below, our weekly collections do not cover the full cost of our programs and activities.  Moreover, we depend on the Advent Appeal to make up a substantial part of the difference.  To contribute, please see the contribution form below, or go to our website, www.dignitny.org.  You can now contribute by using Zelle, a credit card, a check, or through online banking.

As part of our ongoing commitment to social justice, we will continue our tradition of contributing 10% of our Advent Appeal to the Trinity Place Shelter for LGBTQIA+ youth on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. This outstanding organization provides transitional housing and supportive services for up to 18 months for 10 young homeless adults at a time.

To help enrich our experience of Advent, we will be offering digital prayer resources that can be accessed through our website.  We also invite you to join DignityUSA’s weekly online Advent Reflection Series, starting on December 3. Visit www.dignityusa.org to register.

We look forward to seeing you at St. John’s or online for our Christmas Eve liturgy on Wednesday, December 24, at 6:30 PM Eastern.  Our regular weekly liturgies will be held every Sunday in December at 6:30 PM Eastern. There will be no liturgy on New Year’s Eve.

With our warmest wishes for a peaceful and joyful Advent and Christmas, and a holy and healthy New Year,

The Steering Committee of Dignity/New York

Chris Alberti, Robert Brande, Nicholas Cimato, Danny Larkin, James Osbourn, Lewis Speaks-Tanner, and Jeff Stone

********************************************************************

You may contribute using a credit card by clicking on the “Donate” button at www.dignityusa.org and selecting Dignity New York. You may also mail a check made out to Dignity/New York to:

Dignity/New York, Inc.

PO Box 1554, FDR Station

New York, NY 10150-1554

Please indicate on the memo line that the contribution is for the Advent Appeal. You may also join or renew your membership, which is a joint membership in Dignity/New York and DignityUSA, by mailing in the form below or at www.dignityusa.org. The annual fee is $60 for an individual, $120 for a couple, and $160 for a household. However, we make membership available to all regardless of financial ability, so please let us know if you would like to become a member and your finances are limited.

If your donation is meant to cover both Advent Appeal and Membership, please clearly indicate that on the check and form to expedite membership processing.

title: Election Results for Steering Committee
body: Congratulations on those elected for a two year term beginning November 1, 2025 ending October 31, 2027:  James O., Jeff S., Nick C. and Robert B.  They will join members whose term ends October 31, 2026: Chris A, Danny L, and Lewis S.

title: Ballots for the Steering Committee Have Been Sent Out
body:
Elections for the Dignity/New York Steering Committee have now begun. The Elections Committee sent ballots to all members on Saturday, September 13 at 9:00 AM. Members who have not yet voted will receive up to three reminders. If you believe you should have received a ballot but did not, please contact the Elections Committee at elections@dignityny.org.

We also encourage you to join or renew your DignityUSA membership, as membership gives you the right to vote in our local elections. Financial assistance for membership is available; please speak with Chris Alberti or email him at treasurer@dignityny.org. Assistance is available in any amount. Anyone who renews or joins between now and September 21 will receive an electronic ballot. If you are unsure whether your membership is current, please contact us at dignitynewyork@gmail.com or reach out directly to DignityUSA. If you prefer to pay by check, Chris Alberti can help process your membership....

The Steering Committee is made up of members serving two-year terms, which conclude on October 31 of the given year. Those whose terms end on October 31, 2025, are Robert Brande, James Osbourn, and Jeff Stone. Those whose terms end on October 31, 2026, are Chris Alberti, Danny Larkin, and Lewis Speaks-Tanner.

Key Dates in the 2025 Election Cycle

  • **Sunday, August 24 (by noon):** Nomination Petitions became available. Candidates must gather 10 signatures to qualify.
  • **Wednesday, September 10 at 7:00 PM:** Candidates’ Forum conducted online via Zoom.
  • **Saturday, September 13 (ballots sent):** Election Buddy ballots were emailed to all members. Members who have not voted will receive up to three reminders. Questions about ballots should be directed to elections@dignityny.org. Couples who share one email address received two distinct ballots. If you would like one ballot sent to the other person’s address, please contact elections@dignityny.org.
  1. **Friday, September 12 (deadline to ):** Requests for paper mail-in ballots must be received by the Elections Committee. Requests may be made by emailing elections@dignityny.org (please type “MAIL-IN BALLOT” in the subject line) or by calling Ben Speaks-Tanner at 703-864-1724.
  • **Saturday, September 20 (postmark deadline):** Mail-in ballots must be postmarked by this date and received no later than midnight, Friday, September 26, 2025. Please return ballots as soon as possible after receiving them.
  • **Sunday, September 21, 2025 (by 11:00 PM):** Elections conclude. All votes must be submitted online by this time. Only currently enrolled members of Dignity/New York may participate in the election.

title: Steering Committee Nominations Now Open!
body:
Nominations to serve on the Steering Committee are now open and will remain so until the Candidates’ Forum on Wednesday, September 10, 2025. The Nomination Petition is available electronically, and you may also print a blank copy or pick one up at church next Sunday.
Membership in Dignity/New York is through DignityUSA. If the $60 membership fee presents a challenge, please know that assistance is available — you are welcome to speak with a member of our Steering Committee or email dignitynewyork@gmail.com, and we will be glad to help.


2025 ELECTIONS NOTICE SENT TO MEMBERS AND THOSE WHOSE MEMBERSHIP HAS LAPSE WITHIN THE LAST TWO YEARS

The members of Dignity/NY are invited to participate in the annual election of the Steering Committee of Dignity/NY, the governing body of Dignity/NY, pursuant to the bylaws of this Chapter and vote for candidates standing for election to the Steering Committee.

NOMINATING PETITIONS for prospective candidates will be available online from Sunday, August 24, 2025 until Wednesday, September 10, 2025. Nominating petitions can be completed both electronically or by paper. An email will be sent to all members of record with a link to a Google Document containing the electronic nominating petitions and paper nominations may be picked up at church.

Under 7.2 of our bylaws, up to five (5) people are up for election in years that end in an odd number and up to four (4) people will be elected in even numbers years. People are elected for two-year terms.

The terms of three current Steering Committee members (Robert Brande, James Osbourn and Jeff Stone) will expire on October 31, 2025 while the terms of three elected last year (Chris Alberti, Danny Larkin and Lewis Speaks-Tanner) will continue for one more year.
 Under 4.1, our bylaws envision a Steering Committee of nine (9) people, although that is not a requirement. However, there must be a minimum of five (5) members. Therefore, up to six (6) people may be elected to serve on the Steering Committee this year, five (5) for two-year terms that will expire on October 31, 2027 and one (1) for a one-year term that will expire on October 31, 2026. 
WHO MAY STAND FOR ELECTION
Under 8.5 of our bylaws, any person who has been a member of Dignity/NY or DignityUSA for one year within the month of election and who has not been removed from any position within the organization for cause may stand as a candidate for the Steering Committee upon submission of a valid Petition of Nomination. The Elections Committee shall accept as valid any Petition of Nomination signed by ten (10) members in good standing so long it has been received before commencement of the Candidates Forum.

WHO MAY VOTE
All people who are enrolled as members of Dignity/NY upon the night elections conclude may vote. Persons who are not carried as current members on the most recent DignityUSA roster may join, renew or be reinstated as members on or before Sunday, September 21 and may vote. If you feel your membership has lapsed or have any questions about membership, you should email elections@dignityny.org.

THE FOLLOWING ARE DATES OF IMPORTANCE IN OUR 2025 CYCLE OF ELECTIONS
WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 10 @ 7PM– A CANDIDATES FORUM will be conducted online via ZOOM. People who wish to offer themselves for election will have an opportunity to present their programs and or/respond to question from their peers and members of our online congregation. (8.7) Candidates may also post written statements on our website. Election Buddy (a simple online app very much like Survey Monkey) will be sent out ASAP after the Forum to all members of record. If you can vote electronically via Election Buddy, you are requested to do so for ease of counting votes. Anyone with questions about their ballot should email elections@dignityny.org.

REQUESTS FOR PAPER MAIL-IN BALLOTS must be received by the Elections Committee no later than FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 12, 2025. This request must be done either online at elections@dignityny.org (please type “MAIL-IN BALLOT” in the subject line) or phone Ben Speaks-Tanner at 703-864-1724. Mail-In Ballots must be postmarked by Saturday, September 20, 2025 and received no later than midnight Friday, September 26, 2025. Please mail them back as soon as possible after receiving them.

SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 21, 2025: ELECTIONS CONCLUDE Currently enrolled members of Dignity/NY must vote either online before 11PM on SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 21, 2025 or by Mail-In Ballot as described above. (8.2)

[This paragraph below was included in the mailings.  The expiration date is the key element whether you can vote without renewing.  If you renew, especially when you send a check, let the Election Committee know. via email] YOU HAVE RECEIVED THIS NOTICE BECAUSE your name on the most recent membership roster received from DignityUSA. This qualifies you as an Elector of Dignity/NY under 8.8 of our bylaws. Please note if your membership has lapsed before September 1 st , you will not be able to vote in this election. If it expires within the month of September, you will be able to vote and we hope you will renew your membership as soon as possible. If your membership has lapsed and you renew or have proof that you renewed, please email elections@dignityny.org and let us know so we can make sure you have a ballot and are able to vote.

title: Join us this Saturday for Our Pride Liturgy and Social!
2025 Pride Appeal
body:
June 1, 2025

 

Dear Members and Friends of Dignity/New York,

The theme of this year’s NYC Pride celebration is Rise Up: Pride in Protest.  With all the legal and political threats that the LGBTQIA+ community is currently facing, this is certainly an appropriate theme.  Dignity/New York has its own proud history of protest, and we will stand with the entire LGBTQIA+ community in fighting to protect our hard-won rights and defending the most vulnerable among us, particularly transgender people.

In the Catholic community, we are experiencing a remarkable moment of challenge and change with the election of the first American-born pope.  Despite some disappointing early comments on the nature of marriage, we hope that Pope Leo XIV will continue with the more open and pastoral approach to LGBTQIA+ people taken by Pope Francis.  

As we do each year during this season of Pride, we are asking for your continued financial support.  The attached financial report shows our income and expenses over the first six months of the current fiscal year.  As you know, we count heavily on our Pride Appeal to help make up the difference between our weekly collections and our annual expenses.  This year, we are looking forward to the first DignityUSA national conference in three years, which several of our members will be attending.  With your help, we will be able to assist some of them with financial support.

We are sending out this year’s Pride Appeal by physical mail as well as email.  The Pride Appeal will also be posted on our website: www.dignityny.org  You may respond by sending a check to our mailbox (address below), by using the donate button on our website, or by online banking.

You may also use the reply form to renew your annual membership, which is a joint membership in Dignity/New York and DignityUSA.  The fee is $60 per individual, or $120 per couple.  However, membership is available to all regardless of financial ability, so please let us know if you would like to be a member but need financial assistance to do so.

Our annual Pride Liturgy and reception will be held on Saturday, June 28, at St. John’s, starting at a new time: 3:00 PM.  We hope this new time will allow our members and friends to participate in more of the other events of Pride weekend, including the Dyke March.  It should also allow us to enjoy a leisurely late afternoon picnic in the beautiful courtyard at St. John’s, weather permitting.

On Sunday, June 29, we will hold our annual Witness at St. Patrick’s Cathedral and take part in the NYC Pride March.  As always, we will have striking custom T-shirts for all participants in the Witness and March, designed for us by our own Daniel Velasquez.

We thank you in advance for your continuing support for our community, and all your many contributions of time, talent, and treasure.  We look forward to seeing you at our Pride activities and throughout the coming year at our regular Sunday night liturgies, both in person and virtually!

 

The Steering Committee of Dignity/New York

Chris Alberti, Robert Brande, Danny Larkin, James Osbourn, Lewis Speaks-Tanner, Jeff Stone

 

********************************************************************

New York, NY 10150-1554. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

title: Celebrating Pride with Dignity/New York
body:
Our Pride Liturgy will be on June 28th in St. John’s in the Village Church, 218 West 11th St at NEW TIME - 3PM.

There are various activities in the evening. Please join us in the garden after the Pride liturgy for a festive empanadas reception with choice of Chicken, beef, vegetable and portobello mushroom options.  Also, rice, beans and salads.Sangria, sparkling water and soft drinks. Dessert, of course.

For catering purposes, please let us know if you’re coming and if you’re bringing guests rsvp@dignityny.org.

Witness at St, Patrick’s Cathedral

Sunday, June 29th  at 10 am at the northwest corner of the Cathedral at the corner of Fifth Ave. and East 51st Street. Be there 10 minutes before the witness is to start. We will be there for one half hour and join everyone at the March on West 29th St. Please see Lewis or email him at dignitynewyork@gmail.com for a spot in the witness.

Pride March

Sunday, June 29th down Fifth Avenue. We are in Section One; line up is at 11 am. Further details coming next week.

title: Congratulations to Pope Leo XIV
body: Congratulations to Pope Leo XIV. We hope that he will continue the work of Pope Francis. No Pope is perfect nor anyone is prefect. We remain hopeful for a future where equality and diversity eliminates homophobia, misogeny and transphobia have been eliminated. Unfortunately, it will take time. We will continue to speak out for our community. There have been media enquiring about the new Pope. Jeff Stone and Marianne Duddy-Burke have quotes In articles as well as leaders from other progressive Dignity groups.

title: Join Us this Easter Season!
body: We welcome you to join us as we celebrate the Easter Season for Eucharistic liturgy at 6:30 pm. Or remotely via Zoom. Easter Season goes from Easte Sunday (4/20) through Pentecost (6/8)

title: Ash Wednesday - March 5, 2025  begins the Lenten Season
body:
Join us for our Ash Wednesday Service, which will be online only - The Center did not have a room available. The service will begin at 6:00 pm Wednesday, March 5, 2025 using the Sunday Zoom liturgy link. If you would like to read, please email dignitynewyork@gmail.com to let us know.

2 Lenten Evening Prayer will be on Thursday, March 13, 2025 at 7:30 pm using the same Sunday Zoom link. If you would like to read, please email dignitynewyork@gmail.com to let us know.

3 Good Friday Service will be at the Center on April 18 at 6 :15 pm and broadcast via Zoom. If you would like to read, please email dignitynewyork@gmail.com to let us know.

4 In addition to the Little Books for Lent and Easter, we will be sending out a new Lenten weekly reflection/activity, "Vincent Van Gogh and the Beauty of Lent". We will have some paper copies available at church. The creative design by Salt Project is meant to be used anywhere - we will send it out digitally to the community. We will provide more information next week.

*********************************************************************

The Little Black Book for Lent and the Little White Book for Easter have arrived and will be available for those who want to reserve a copy. Email dignitynewyork@gmail.com if you wish to obtain a copy either for pick up at St. John's or by mail. We will gladly mail them to anyone who wishes. Let us know the number of books you need, your name and address.
*********************************************************************

Dignity/NY invites you to journey through lent this year with Vincent Van Gogh. Our theme for Lent 2025 is hope. Van Gogh paid close attention to detail in his artwork. He had a great ability to notice beauty in the world around him and reflect that beauty on a canvas. As LGBTQIA Catholics, Van Gogh's work gives us an opportunity to reflect on hope, forgiveness, and finding beauty in darkness. Vincent Van Gogh and the Beauty of Lent is a devotional with reflections for Ash Wednesday, each Sunday in Lent, and Holy Week.

title: Chapter's Steering Committee Nominations Are Now Open
body:

title: Celebrate Pride 2024 with Dignity/New York

title: March 8, 2024 International Women's Day
body:
March 8, 2024 marks International Women's Day. From https://www.internationalwomensday.com/theme on how you can get involved to "Inspire Inclusion":

Get involved for IWD 2024
With well over a century of history and change, the first International Women's Day (IWD) was held in March 1911. IWD isn't country, group or organization specific. It's a day of collective global activism and celebration that belongs to all those committed to forging women's equality.

World-renowned feminist, journalist and activist, Gloria Steinem, reportedly once explained:
"The story of women's struggle for equality belongs to no single feminist nor to any one organization but to the collective efforts of all who care about human rights."

So together, let's all help fight the good fight. All IWD activity is valid, that's what makes IWD so inclusive. Join in and make IWD your day by doing what you can to support and advance women.

Committing to inspire inclusion
IWD2024 theme

When women aren't present, we must ask: "If not, why not?"

When women are discriminated against, we must call out poor practice.

When the treatment of women is not equitable, we must take action.

And we must do this each time, every time.

title: DignityUSA Speaks Out After Cecilia Gentili's Funeral at St. Patrick's
body:
DignityUSA Executive Director Marianne Duddy-Burke speaks out in Gay City News on the controversy surrounding the funeral of Cecilia Gentili at St. Patrick's Cathedral:
Marianne Duddy-Burke, the executive director of DignityUSA, which represents LGBTQ Catholics, disagreed with the church’s response and voiced skepticism about the archdiocese’s claims.
“I don’t know how the archdiocese’s staff could have been so ignorant about Cecilia when the request was made,” Duddy-Burke told Gay City News in an interview on Feb. 19. “Our church should be offering hospitality to anyone — it is as simple as that. Condemning people for what they do in grief and how they tell the truth of a life is just wrong.”
Duddy-Burke described Gentili as an individual who used her status in New York’s community to “do good for others at the margins” and that she “modeled what Christian service was about, even if she didn’t claim the title Christian.”
“To take the step of publicly condemning the funeral just seems unwise, unchristian, and uncharitable,” she said.
Full story can be found: https://gaycitynews.com/archdiocese-new-york-criticizes-cecilia-gentili…

title: Epiphany Proclamation 2024
body:
While a day like Christmas is fixed in our minds and on the calendars on December 25th, many of the important feasts of the Church year move, based upon the date that Easter is set. Easter changes each year moving to the Sunday after the "Paschal Full Moon," and can fall between March 22 and April 25.

In ancient times before calendars were common, most people did not know the dates for the upcoming Liturgical year. On Epiphany Sunday, the upcoming dates were "proclaimed" after the gospel or after communion in this way:

Dear friends, the glory of our God has shone upon us, and shall ever be manifest among us, until the day of the return of the Anointed One.

Through the rhythms of times and seasons let us celebrate the mysteries of salvation.

Let us recall the year's liturgical culmination, the Easter Triduum of Jesus the Christ: his last supper, his crucifixion, his burial, and his rising, Pascal Mystery celebrated between the evening of the Twenty-eighth day of March and the evening of the Thirtieth day of March,  Easter Sunday being on the Thirty-first day of March.

Each Easter -- as on each Sunday -- the Holy Church makes present the great and saving deed by which Jesus has forever conquered sin and death. From Easter then are reckoned all the days we keep holy.

Ash Wednesday, the beginning of Lent, will occur on the Fourteenth day of February.

The Ascension of Jesus the Christ will be commemorated on Sunday, the Twelfth day of May.

Pentecost, joyful conclusion of the season of Easter, will be celebrated on the Nineteenth day of May.

Gay Pride Liturgy will be celebrated on Saturday, the Twenty-ninth day of June.

Commemoration of the Stonewall Riots will be celebrated on Sunday, the Thirtieth day of June. 

And, this year the First Sunday of Advent will be on the First day of December.

Likewise the pilgrim Church proclaims the Passover of the Anointed One in the feasts of the holy Mother of God, in the feasts of the Apostles and Saints, and in the commemoration of the faithful departed.

And our community will celebrate its own Anniversary on Sunday, the Twenty-seventh day of October for the Fifty-second time.

To Jesus Christ the Anointed One, who was, who is, and who is to come, God of time and history, be endless praise, for ever and ever. Amen.

title: We Celebrate Epiphany!  Epiphany Home Blessing & Marking the Lintel
body:
PRAYER FOR BLESSING CHALK

Jesus, through your Incarnation and birth in true human form, you have made all the earthy holy. We now ask your blessing upon this simple gift of your creation – chalk. We use it as a tool to teach our children, and they use it as a tool in their play and games. Now, with your blessing, may it become a tool for us to mark the doors of our home with the symbols of your wise servants who, so long ago, came to worship and adore you in your first home.

EPIPHANY HOME BLESSING

Some Christians bless their homes on Epiphany each year. With chalk, they write an inscription on the inside lintel above the front door. The series of the numbers, letters and crosses changes only slightly from year to year.

For the year 2024, the line will read as follows:

20+C+M+B+24

Because Epiphany comes so near the beginning of the New Year, the year numbers represent an annual renewal of God’s blessing.

The letters have two meanings. They are the initials of the traditional names of the magi: Caspar, Melchior and Balthazar. They also abbreviate the Latin words “Christus mansionem benedicat.” “May Christ bless this house.”

The crosses represent Christ, who we invoke, and the saintliness of the magi. The inscription is made above the front door, so that all who enter and depart this year may enjoy God’s blessing. The month of January still bears the name of the Roman god Janus, the doorkeeper of heaven and patron of the beginning and the end of things. This blessing adds a Christian dimension to the traditional observance of the first month. The inscription is made of chalk, a product of clay, which recalls the human nature taken by God’s eternal word in this holy season.

If you want to bless your home this Epiphany, read the opening verses of John’s Gospel, pray the Lord’s Prayer, then write the inscription for this year above your front door with chalk.

title: Pride Appeal
body:
Dear Members and Friends of Dignity/New York,

Happy Pride! As we look back over the past year, we have much to be proud of, from our 50th anniversary celebrations to our progressive, inclusive liturgies in person and online, our warm and welcoming community, and our many social and outreach activities. We continue to be a unique community of LGBTQI+ people and allies within the Roman Catholic tradition, where we can speak our truth without fear and be our whole selves.

As usual, we have a busy schedule of Pride activities planned. We will be participating in the Queens Pride Parade on Sunday, June 4. Our annual Pride Liturgy and reception will be held on Saturday, June 24, at 6:30 PM at St. John’s. We are excited to share that our homilist will be Maddie Marlett, co-facilitator of the Dignity Young Adult Caucus. On Sunday, June 25, we will take part in our annual Witness at St. Patrick’s Cathedral and then the NYC Pride March.

We come to you once again, as we do every year at this time, to ask for your financial support. The attached financial report shows our income and expenses over the first six months of the current fiscal year. As you may know, we count heavily on our Pride Appeal to help cover the difference between our weekly collections and our annual expenses.

In addition to our usual activities, this summer two of our members, Brian Frank and Catherine Buck, will be among the pilgrims representing us and all of DignityUSA at World Youth Day in Lisbon, Portugal. The Steering Committee would like to make a significant contribution to their expenses, and your contributions will help us do that. By being present as out LGBTQI+ people, our pilgrims will be a beacon of hope and affirmation for all the LGBTQI+ people throughout our church who cannot be visible.

This year we are sending out physical Pride Appeal letters as well as email letters. The Pride Appeal letter will also be posted on our website: www.dignityny.org You may respond by sending a check in the enclosed reply envelope to our mailbox (address below), by using the donate button on our website, or by online banking.

You may also use the reply form to renew your annual membership, which is a joint membership in Dignity/New York and DignityUSA. The fee is $60 per individual, or $120 per couple. However, membership is available to all regardless of financial ability, so please let us know if you would like to be a member but need financial assistance to do so.

We thank you in advance for your continuing generosity, and look forward to seeing you at our Pride activities and throughout the coming year!

The Steering Committee of Dignity/New York

Chris Alberti, Danny Larkin, Tom McLoughlin, James Osbourn, Lewis Speaks-Tanner, Jeff Stone, and Daniel Velásquez

title: Members of Dignity/New York going to the screening of Let's Kiss
body:
A few members of Dignity/New York are planning to see "Let's Kiss". See Chris Alberti for details. People must arrive early.

Mon, 04/17/2023 - 6:30pm

Let's Kiss
Franco Grillini - History of a Gentle Revolution

http://www.casaitaliananyu.org/events/lets-kiss

Documentary Screening
Let's Kiss
Franco Grillini - History of a Gentle Revolution
(Italy, 2021, 85 min.)

In ITALIAN with ENGLISH subtitles

Directed by
Filippo Vendemmiati

Followed by a conversation with:
Franco Grillini
Filippo Vendemmiati
Rachel Love, NYU
Brian DeGrazia, Independent scholar

The film is about Franco Grillini, a somewhat late-blooming gay politician from Bologna, born in 1955 into a farming family, with a degree in education, who has always been active in the fight for the recognition of gay, lesbian, and transsexual civil rights. Through the story told directly by its protagonist, the biopic, with a light tone and using original documentary material, reconstructs over thirty years of political history, bearing witness to a tough and gentle fight in the name of dignity and equality. This journey – also a sentimental one – touches upon the places of Grillini's life: from his birth home in the country to his university, from the headquarters of old parties that no longer exist to Parliament, as well as in the streets and squares of Gay Pride parades, from Rome to New York.

The stages in Franco Grillini’s life are punctuated by struggles and victories – from the tragic AIDS years, marked by death and the stigmatizing of homosexual relations, to the first same-sex marriages, and the still-ongoing battle for stepchild adoption – but also the evolution of the approach to a topic which still today, even though it concerns millions of people, is strongly divisive if not ignored. Grillini talks about public and private aspects with serenity and humor, in a language that his Bolognese accent transforms into a musical lilt, about his firm yet serene hope for a future without lives lived in fear of social stigma, for the right to health, and the full expression of love and affection.

This film collects stories of love and political battles, both inside and outside of Parliament, insuppressible driving forces for change and a zest for life.

title: Advent Appeal
body:
November 18, 2022

Dear Members and Friends of Dignity/New York,

Once again, we are approaching the prayerful season of Advent and the beginning of a new liturgical year. We just concluded our 50th anniversary year with a wonderful dinner and liturgy. We couldn’t have reached this milestone without you, and we need your continued support to sustain our beautiful community and advance our mission for many more years to come.

As you can see from the financial report below, we had some unusually large expenses over this past fiscal year because of our support of the DignityUSA national conference in July and our own anniversary and Pride celebrations. Our weekly contributions do not cover the full cost of our activities, and we drew on our savings to make up the difference. We depend on the Advent Appeal to help replenish those savings.

As part of our ongoing commitment to social justice, we will continue our tradition of contributing 10% of our Advent Appeal to the Trinity Place Shelter for LGBTQ+ youth on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. This excellent organization provides transitional housing and supportive services for up to 18 months for 10 young adults at a time.

To help enrich our experience of Advent, we are offering to each member of our community a free copy of The Little Blue Book Advent and Christmas Seasons 2022-2023. If you are unable to pick one up at St. John’s, please email dignitynewyork@gmail.com with your address and we will mail one to you. We also invite you to participate in DignityUSA’s weekly online Advent Reflection Series, starting on November 30. Visit www.dignityusa.org to register.

We look forward to seeing you at St. John’s or online for our regular Sunday evening liturgies at 6:30 PM EST, and for our Christmas Eve liturgy on Saturday, December 24, at 6:30 PM EST. There will be no liturgy on Sunday, December 25.

With our thanks in advance for your unfailing generosity, we send you best wishes and prayers for a safe and peaceful Advent and Christmas, and a Happy New Year.

The Steering Committee of Dignity/New York
Chris Alberti, Danny Larkin, Tom McLoughlin, James Osbourn,
Lewis Speaks-Tanner, Jeff Stone, Daniel Velásquez

title: 2022 Elections Notice and Petition of Nomination
body:
2022 ELECTIONS NOTICE
[This is a modified notice.  Dignity/New York members will receive a letter indicating that they are a member with their expiration date or if they have lapsed within the last 3 months when their membership expired.  If you do not receive the letter in the mail, you may not be a Dignity/New York member; please join or renew your membership.  If you have questions  about your membership, please email Elections@dignityny.org   To start petitioning or sign nomination petition, go to the comment below for the Petition of Nomination If you cannot open the Petition of Nomination, email elections@dignityny.org.

The members of Dignity/NY are invited to participate in the annual election of the Steering Committee of Dignity/NY, the governing body of Dignity/NY, pursuant to the bylaws of this Chapter and vote for candidates standing for election to the Steering Committee.

NOMINATING PETITIONS for prospective candidates will be available online from Sunday, August 21, 2022 until Thursday, September 15, 2022. Nominating petitions will be completed electronically. An email will be sent to all members of record with a link to a Google Document containing the nominating petitions.
Under 7.2 of our bylaws, up to five (5) people are up for election in years that end in an odd number and up to four (4) people will be elected in even numbers years. People are elected for two-year terms.

The terms of four current Steering Committee members (Chris Alberti, Danny Larkin, Tom McLoughlin and Lewis Speaks-Tanner) will expire on October 31, 2022 while the terms of two elected last year (James Osbourn and Jeff Stone) will continue for one more year.

Under 4.1, our bylaws envision a Steering Committee of nine (9) people, although that is not a requirement. However, there must be a minimum of five (5) members. Therefore, up to seven (7) people may be elected to serve on the Steering Committee this year, four (4) for two-year terms that will expire on October 31, 2024 and three (3) for one-year terms that will expire on October 31, 2023. If necessary, determination of two-year terms and one-year terms will be decided according to the number of votes received by each candidate.

WHO MAY STAND FOR ELECTION
Under 8.5 of our bylaws, any person who has been a member of Dignity/NY or Dignity USA for one year within the month of election and who has not been removed from any position within the organization for cause may stand as a candidate for the Steering Committee upon submission of a valid Petition of Nomination. The Elections Committee shall accept as valid any Petition of Nomination signed by ten (10) members in good standing so long it has been received before commencement of the Candidates Forum.

WHO MAY VOTE
All people who are enrolled as members of Dignity/NY upon the night elections conclude may vote.  Persons who are not carried as current members on the most recent Dignity USA roster may join, renew or be reinstated as members on or before Sunday, September 25 and may vote. If you feel your membership has lapsed or have any questions about membership, you should email Elections@dignityny.org.

THE FOLLOWING ARE DATES OF IMPORTANCE IN OUR 2022 CYCLE OF ELECTIONS

THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 15 @ 7PM– A CANDIDATES FORUM will be conducted online via ZOOM. People who wish to offer themselves for election will have an opportunity to present their programs and or/respond to question from their peers and members of our online congregation. (8.7) Candidates may also post written statements on our website. Election Buddy (a simple online app very much like Survey Monkey) will be sent out ASAP after the Forum to all members of record. If you can vote electronically via Election Buddy, you are requested to do so for ease of counting votes. Anyone with questions about their ballot should email Elections@dignityny.org.

REQUESTS FOR PAPER MAIL-IN BALLOTS must be received by the Elections Committee no later than FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 16, 2022. This request must be done either online at Elections@dignityny.org (please type “MAIL-IN BALLOT” in the subject line) or phone Ben Speaks-Tanner at 703-864-1724.  Mail-In Ballots must be postmarked by Saturday, September 24, 2022 and received no later than midnight Friday, September 30, 2022.  Please mail them back as soon as possible after receiving them.

SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 25: ELECTIONS CONCLUDE Currently enrolled members of Dignity/NY must vote either online before 11PM on SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 25, 2022 or by Mail-In Ballot as described above. (8.2)

title: Contribute to the Annual Pride Appeal
body:
May 29, 2022

Dear Members and Friends of Dignity/New York,

Happy Birthday to us! In 2022, we celebrate the 50th anniversary of our community. In this Pride season, we certainly have much to be proud of: 50 years of support, worship, and witness. 50 years of working for equality and inclusion for LGBTQI people in the Catholic Church and beyond. 50 years of activism within the broader LGBTQI movement, through the height of the AIDS epidemic, the fight for our civil rights, and the struggle for marriage equality.

The past few years have certainly been tumultuous. During the Covid pandemic, we have innovated with online liturgies and now hybrid liturgies to serve the needs of our community. But we have lived through difficult times before, and have always emerged stronger in our faith and sense of community. Our mission remains as vital today as it was a half century ago.

To mark our 50th anniversary, we are planning many special events throughout 2022, starting with a picnic after our liturgy on Pentecost Sunday, June 5th. We will be participating in the Queens Pride Parade (also Sunday, June 5th) and the Brooklyn Pride Parade (Saturday, June 11th), as well as our annual Witness at St. Patrick’s Cathedral and the NYC Pride March (Sunday, June 26th). Our annual Pride Liturgy will be held on Saturday, June 25th, at 6:30 PM at St. John’s, to be followed by a social with food and drink. We are planning a festive anniversary dinner and liturgy for October. In addition, our Membership Outreach group is planning many social activities throughout the year.

We come to you once again, as we do every year at this time, to ask for your support so that we can continue with all our activities. The attached financial report shows our income and expenses over the first six months of the current fiscal year. As we returned to St. John’s in June 2021, our expenses returned to a more normal and higher level. As you know, we count heavily on our Pride Appeal to help cover the difference between our weekly collections and our annual expenses.

This year we are sending out physical Pride Appeal letters as well as email letters. The Pride Appeal letter is also posted on our website: www.dignityny.org You may respond either by sending a check in the enclosed reply envelope to our mailbox (address below), by using the donate button on our website, or by online banking.

You may also use the reply form to renew your annual membership, which is a joint membership in Dignity/New York and DignityUSA. The fee is now $60 per individual, or $120 per couple. However, membership is available to all regardless of financial ability, so please let us know if you would like to be a member but need financial assistance to do so.

We look forward to seeing you at our activities as we celebrate this exciting anniversary year!

The Steering Committee of Dignity/New York
Chris Alberti, Danny Larkin, Tom McLoughlin, James Osbourn, Lewis Speaks-Tanner, and Jeff Stone

Dignity/New York — member chapter of DignityUSA P.O. Box 1554, FDR Station, New York, NY 10150-1554 646.418.7039 | info@dignityny.org | www.dignityny.org

title: Epiphany Proclamation 2022
body:
While a day like Christmas is fixed in our minds and on the calendars on December 25th, many of the important feasts of the Church year move, based    upon the date that Easter is set. Easter changes each year moving to the Sunday after the "Paschal Full Moon," and can fall between March 22 and April 25.

In ancient times before calendars were common, most people did not know the dates for the upcoming Liturgical year. On Epiphany Sunday, the upcoming dates were "proclaimed" after the gospel or after communion in this way:

Dear people of God, the glory of our God has shone upon us, and shall ever be manifest among us, until the day of the return of the Anointed One.

Through the rhythms of times and seasons let us celebrate the mysteries of salvation.

Let us recall the year's liturgical culmination, the Easter Triduum of Jesus the Christ: his last supper, his crucifixion, his burial, and his rising, Pascal Mystery celebrated between the evening of the Fourteenth day of April and the evening of the Sixteenth day of April, Easter Sunday being on the Seventeenth day of April.

Each Easter -- as on each Sunday -- the Holy Church makes present the great and saving deed by which Jesus has forever conquered sin and death. From Easter then are reckoned all the days we keep holy.

Ash Wednesday, the beginning of Lent, will occur on the Second of March.

The Ascension of Jesus the Christ will be commemorated on Sunday, the Twenty-Ninth of May.

Pentecost, joyful conclusion of the season of Easter, will be celebrated on the Fifth day of June.

Gay Pride Liturgy will be celebrated on Saturday, the Twenty-Fifth of June.

Commemoration of the Stonewall Riots  will be celebrated on Sunday, the Twenty-Sixth of June. 

And, this year the First Sunday of Advent will be on the Twenty-Seventh of November.

Likewise the pilgrim Church proclaims the Passover of the Anointed One in the feasts of the holy Mother of God, in the feasts of the Apostles and Saints, and in the commemoration of the faithful departed.

And our community will celebrate its own Anniversary on Sunday, the Twenty-Third of October for the Fiftieth time.

To Jesus Christ the Anointed One, who was, who is, and who is to come, God of time and history, be endless praise, for ever and ever.
Amen.

title: World AIDS Day - December 1, 2021
body:
For the last 40 years, Dignity/New York has worked and prayed for the day when AIDS will no longer be a health crisis affecting the world.

AIDS PRAYER

For those who have died of AIDS, we pray:

Merciful and loving God,
we ask you to look with favor
on our siblings and friends,
all over the world who have suffered and died of AIDS.

In their illness,
they shared in the suffering and death of Jesus.
May they now share in his resurrection
and be counted among your saints forever.

God, may we, the living draw strength
from the witness of their lives
and become instruments of your peace and consolation.
We pray in Jesus's name. Amen

ORACIÓN DEL SIDA

Dios de misericordia y de amor,
mira con bondad a nuestros hermanos y hermanas
por todo el mundo que sufrieron
y se murieron de SIDA.

En su enfermedad, ellos compartieron en el
sufrimiento y muerte de Jesús.
Que ellos ahora puedan participar
en su resurrección y contarse
entre sus santos y santas para siempre.

Dios, que nosotros, los vivientes,
podamos tomar fuerza del
testigo de sus vidas y llegar a ser
instrumentos de su paz y consuelo.

Te lo pedimos en el nombre de Jesús. Amén.

title: Dignity/New York Advent Appeal 2021
body:
November 28, 2021
Dear Members and Friends of Dignity/New York,

With the arrival of Advent and the beginning of a new liturgical year, we naturally look back upon the past year. It has been a time of transition for our community. After more than fifteen months away, we cautiously returned to in-person liturgies at St. John’s in June, while also offering a Zoom option. Although slightly different in some ways, our liturgies continue to joyfully celebrate who we are as LGBTQ+ Catholics and allies.

We couldn’t have gotten through this challenging period without your generous contributions of time, talent, and treasure. So, we come to you once again, as we do every year at this time, to ask for your continued support.

As you can see from the financial report below, our expenses exceeded our income by about $400. Notably, we received more than one third of our annual income online. Now that we have gone back to St. John’s, most of our expenses have returned to their former levels, but our weekly collections do not fully cover our operating costs. In fact, we depend on our annual Advent Appeal to contribute approximately $5,000 toward our yearly expenses, and we hope we are able to meet that goal this year.

One of the things we pray for during Advent is the coming of justice. In past years, as part of our commitment to social justice, our community has made financial contributions to the Trinity Place Shelter for LGBTQ+ youth on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. This year, in continuation of that tradition, we have committed to contribute 10% of our Advent Appeal to this excellent organization, which provides transitional housing and professional supportive services for up to 18 months for 10 young adults at a time.

To help enrich our experience of Advent, each household in our community has been offered a free physical or electronic copy of The Little Blue Book Advent and Christmas Seasons 2021-2022. Using this book as a resource, we will have three online meetings to reflect on how our Advent and Christmas experience is going. The dates are all on Tuesdays: November 30, December 21, and January 4 at 7:30 PM, using the regular Zoom link for our Sunday liturgy. This can be found in the Worship Aid that can be accessed at www.dignityny.org under Liturgy toward the bottom of the homepage.

As always, we look forward to seeing you every Sunday evening at 6:30 PM EST at St. John’s or online for our regular Sunday liturgies, and for our Christmas Eve liturgy on Friday, December 24, at 6:30 PM EST. We will not have a liturgy on Christmas Day, but will resume our regular Sunday liturgies on December 26.

With our best wishes and prayers for a safe and peaceful Advent and Christmas, and a Happy New Year,

The Steering Committee of Dignity/New York
Chris Alberti, Danny Larkin, Tom McLoughlin, James Osbourn, Lewis Speaks-Tanner, and Jeff Stone

title: Dignity/New York Nominations, Candidates Forum and Elections
body:
Nominations are open. There are five open slots on the Steering Committee. Dignity/New York members can sign a candidates’ petitions or nominate themselves (link is in the announcements at the end of Sunday Worship Aid). Nominations are open until 7 PM on Thursday, September 16, 2021. Candidates must receive the support of ten currently enrolled members of the chapter to stand for election.

Terms of Larry Caputo, James Osbourn, and Jeff Stone will expire on October 31, 2021. Terms of the five elected last year (Chris Alberti, Andrew Jones, Daniel Larkin, Tom McLoughtlin and Lewis Speaks-Tanner) will continue for one more year. However, Andrew's term will end on October 31. 2021 since he is unable to continue due to work responsibilities.

Candidates Forum
The Candidates Forum will be on Zoom on Thursday, September 16, 2021 at 7:30 pm. Email dignitynewyork@gmail.com for the Zoom link or see the end of the Sunday Worship Aid.

Electronic Ballots will be sent out shortly after the Candidates Forum. All persons who are enrolled as members of Dignity/New York upon the night elections conclude may vote. Persons who are not carried as current members on the most recent DignityUSA roster may join, renew or be reinstated as members on or before Sunday, September 26 and vote. If your membership has expired within the last three months, you will be entitled to vote during the chapter’s customary grace period.

We will be using Election Buddy this year. We encourage all members to vote electronically. Anyone having questions about their ballot should email elections@dignityny.org. Dignity/New York is the address that the ballots will be sent from.

Requests for Paper Mail-In Ballots must be received by the Elections Committee not later than Friday, September 17, 2021(Elections@DignityNY.org with subject line "Mail-In Ballot" or phone Gary Spokes). Mail-In Ballots must be postmarked by Saturday, September 25, and received not later than midnight on Friday, October 1, 2021.

The Elections Committee consists of Gary Spokes, Ed Fitzgerald, and Ben Speaks-Tanner.

title: News From the Steering Committee
body:
The Steering Committee met via Zoom on July 13 and August 3. Here are some highlights:

Due to the changing health situation, face coverings are once again required for ALL in the church at St. John’s. They are optional outside, such as in the courtyard. We will continue to monitor the situation closely and will conform to all regulations of St. John’s, the Episcopal Diocese, the city, state, and CDC.

Advance reservations are no long required for attendance at St. John’s. Seating remains socially distanced, six feet apart. Capacity in the church is now approximately 60 people. There should be ample seating for everyone who comes, in designated spots for 1 or 2 people. You may continue to sit by yourself if you wish.

Our hybrid liturgies are going well, with about 25-30 participants each week at St. John’s and a similar number on Zoom.

We could use more volunteers to serve as readers, sacristans, and coordinators. Please contact Larry Caputo (Larry4Card at aol.com) or any Steering Committee member.

We are planning a homecoming party at St. John’s after liturgy on September 19, in the courtyard with refreshments.

We are also planning a special anniversary celebration with refreshments after our anniversary liturgy at St. John’s on October 24, also in the courtyard if weather permits.

We approved a budget for fiscal year 2021-22, which runs from November 1, 2021, through October 31, 2022. It is very similar to the budget we had before the pandemic. We are in good financial condition, but we hope to maintain or improve weekly collections (in-person and online) and our Advent and Pride appeals.

The Diversity Outreach of Dignity/New York (DODNY) has some exciting ideas for community activities starting this fall. We will keep you posted.
Steering Committee elections are coming up in September and you will be receiving more information soon. Please consider whether you would be interested in serving on the committee, or if you would like to nominate someone. At least five spots will be open. Steering Committee meetings will continue to be held via Zoom for the foreseeable future.

A Note about our Finances and the DignityUSA Leadership Stabilization Fund

Last year, the Steering Committee received a request for support of DignityUSA’s Leadership Stabilization Fund, along with a detailed proposal and financial report. The purpose of the fund is to ensure that DignityUSA continues to have capable and effective executive leadership for the next five years. Other large chapters and major donors were also approached, and many have already made significant contributions.

The Steering Committee believes the finances of DignityUSA are well managed and the request is a reasonable and necessary one. Also, we firmly believe that the work of DignityUSA is vital to the success and stability of our local community. DignityUSA, especially through our Executive Director Marianne Duddy-Burke, is our connection to other Dignity members and communities across the US, our link to other progressive Catholic organizations in the US and around the world, our respected voice in national and international media, and a source of support and resources for our local community in many different ways.

After discussions stretching across several meetings, the Steering Committee voted unanimously to contribute $20,000 to the Fund over four years, in installments of $5,000 each. Because of the generosity of our members and friends over the years, a large bequest received some years ago, and a substantial increase in the value of our investments held as a prudent reserve, the Steering Committee believes that this contribution is well within our means and will not have a negative impact on any other needs or priorities of our community.

As we are all aware, the past year and a half have been extraordinary in many different ways. As we begin to emerge into a new era, our finances will adjust to meet new needs and priorities. We are anticipating several major events next year, including Dignity/New York’s 50th anniversary, a return to in-person Pride celebrations, and an in-person DignityUSA national conference in San Diego.

We plan to support all these activities, as well as others that may emerge from discussions within our community. One of the Steering Committee’s goals for the coming year is to develop a strategic financial plan that will allow us to maintain a prudent reserve while making the most effective use possible of our financial resources. Stay tuned for more information in the coming months!

title: Updated Protocols for Attending Liturgy at St. John's effective August 5, 2021
body:
Due to the changing health situation, face coverings are once again required for ALL in the church at St. John’s.  They are optional outside, such as in the courtyard.  We will continue to monitor the situation closely and will conform to all regulations of St. John’s, the Episcopal Diocese, the city, state, and CDC.

Reservations are no longer necessary.  Contact tracing is no longer being done by St. John’s and seating capacity has increased to approximately 60 people.  Six-foot distancing is still required in church so you will need to sit in designated spaces for one or two people.  You may continue to sit by yourself if you wish.

In addition, you are invited to exchange a Sign of Peace as you are comfortable doing, but please remain near your seat in order to maintain social distancing, and please respect everyone’s comfort level.

title: IMPORTANT CHANGES REGARDING ATTENDANCE AT ST JOHN’S  - July 13, 2021
body:
Fr. Graeme, Rector at St. John’s, has recently advised us of changes in the safety protocols at St. John’s, which we are obliged to follow.  In accord with those changes, we have also changed our protocols.  

Reservations are no longer necessary.  Contact tracing is no longer being done by St. John’s and seating capacity has increased to approximately 60 people.  Six-foot distancing is still required in church so you will need to sit in designated spaces for one or two people.  You may continue to sit by yourself if you wish.

Face-coverings in church are now optional for those who are fully vaccinated, including presiders. Those who are as yet unvaccinated must wear face-coverings during worship (and in Revelation Gallery) but should consider face-coverings optional outdoors.

In addition, you are invited to exchange a Sign of Peace as you are comfortable doing, but please remain near your seat in order to maintain social distancing, and please respect everyone’s comfort level.

title: Return to St. John's - Reserve Your Seat
body:
Dear friends and members,
You should have received an email last Sunday providing details about our return to St. John’s on June 20. If not, you can find it on the home page of the Dignity/New York website (www.dignityny.org).

As promised, here is further information about reserving your seat. This is necessary because by regulation of St. John’s and the Episcopal Diocese of New York, capacity in the church is currently limited to 40 people in the pews.

There are 20 designed spots throughout the church, socially distanced from one another. They may be occupied by either one or two people.

There are three options for seating:
1. Sitting by yourself.
2. Sitting with one other person of your choice. (Please include name of this person.)
3. Reserving as a single person, but being willing to sit with another person from the congregation if necessary in order to maximize seating capacity.

Please send an email to reserve@dignityny.org with the date of the liturgy you are reserving for in the subject line. The first available date is June 20. For now, we can accept reservations only for one week at a time, starting on the Monday prior to the liturgy in question. Reservations for June 20 will open on Monday, June 14.

PLEASE INDICATE CLEARLY WHETHER YOU CHOOSE OPTION 1, 2, OR 3.
There is a limited overflow capacity of 8 seats in the common room, which we will use if necessary. Walk-ins will be permitted if space is available, but they will need to provide contact information in the event contact tracing is necessary. Reserved seats will be held until 6:35 PM, but will then be given to walk-ins if there are any.

We all look forward to the time when capacity and seating restrictions are no longer necessary, but for the time being these are the regulations we must follow.

Thanks for your cooperation, and we look forward to seeing you back at St. John’s.

The Steering Committee of Dignity/New York
Chris Alberti, Larry Caputo, Andrew Jones, Danny Larkin, Tom McLoughlin, James Osbourn, Lewis Speaks-Tanner, and Jeff Stone

title: Dignity/New York Pride Appeal 2021
body:
June 8, 2021

Dear Members and Friends of Dignity/New York,

The members of the Steering Committee send you warm and hopeful greetings at the beginning of Pride Month 2021. Thanks be to God and science, we are in a far different place than we were a year ago. Fifteen months after we were forced to suspend services at St. John’s, we are now planning to return there and resume our regular Sunday liturgy schedule on June 20. (You should have recently received a separate email about this, which is now posted on our website: www.dignityny.org)

Once again, we want to thank our Liturgy Committee for their tremendous work on our Zoom liturgies, which have sustained us through a dark time of isolation and uncertainty, and have become the “gold standard” of online liturgies. We hope to bring some aspects of those liturgies into St. John’s, and will keep you updated.

We know that for many of you, the pandemic has created great financial hardship. Nevertheless, Dignityyou have been extremely generous with your financial support, which has enabled us to meet our ongoing fixed expenses of rent, insurance, phone, storage, and so on. A report of our income and expenses over the past six months has been appended to this letter below. As we return to St. John’s, our expenses will naturally return to a more normal and higher level. As you know, we count on our Pride Appeal to help cover the difference between our weekly collections and our expenses.

Because we did not meet physically to assemble a mailing, this appeal will be sent by email only. You may contribute by using the donate button on our website (www.dignityny.org), by online banking, or by mailing checks to our mailbox (address below). A reply form is appended below, which you may print out if you wish and return if you mail your contribution. However, this is not necessary.

If you mail a check, please indicate on the memo line that it is a contribution to the Pride Appeal. Please also indicate if you would like a portion of your contribution to be used to renew your annual membership, which is a joint membership in Dignity/New York and DignityUSA. The fee is now $60 per individual, or $120 per couple. However, we make membership available to all regardless of financial ability, so please let us know if you would like to be a member but need financial assistance to do so.

As we emerge from the pandemic, we are entering a new era in our life as a spiritual community, and in our individual lives. We know that the pandemic has been a time of loss, fear, and trauma, as well as resilience. We know that many of us are grieving lost loved ones and lost opportunities, and are continuing to feel anxiety as we face rapidly changing realities.

As we start to gather physically once again, we will draw upon the strength of our faith tradition and one another to heal and to grow, as we have always done. Thank you for your continued support of our beloved community, and our message of equality and inclusion for LGBTQ+ people in the Catholic Church and beyond. As we have seen from the Vatican’s recent denial of blessings to same-sex couples, and DignityUSA’s own Catholic Pride Blessing in response, we still have a lot of work to do, and a vital role to play.

Blessings to you at Pride and always!

The Steering Committee of Dignity/New York

Chris Alberti, Larry Caputo, Andrew Jones, Danny Larkin, Tom McLoughlin, James Osbourn, Lewis Speaks-Tanner, and Jeff Stone

Financial Report (PDF attachment has the financial report and slip to enclose donation by check)
November 1st 2020 - May 1st 2021

title: Return to St. John's on Sunday, June 20, 2021
body:
Dear Members and Friends,

We have very exciting and joyous news! After fifteen months away, we will be returning to St. John’s for in-person liturgies. We will resume our regular weekly schedule on Sunday, June 20, at 6:30 PM. Our Pride liturgy will be held at St. John’s on the following Sunday, June 27, at 6:30 PM. This is a change from our past tradition of holding our Pride service on the Saturday evening of Pride weekend, which we anticipate will be for this year only.

We have heard your voices in our recent online survey and the virtual town hall meeting. A majority of our members are eager to return to in-person services, but many are also mindful of the online community that has formed during the pandemic. We thank the Liturgy Committee for their tremendous efforts in producing our online Zoom liturgies every single week since March 15, 2020. We are looking at ways to bring some aspects of the Zoom liturgies to St. John’s, and to allow online participants to see and hear what is happening there. We anticipate this will be an evolving situation, and we will need a committed team of volunteers to help run the technology.

We are required to follow all the safety measures that remain in place at St. John’s. We must wear masks indoors at all times and sit in designated spots for social distancing. The windows will be kept open as much as possible. Capacity is currently limited to 40 people in the pews, sitting either singly or in groups of 2, so we will be asking you to reserve a spot in advance by email.

There will be three options: sitting by yourself, sitting with another person of your choice, or being willing to sit with another person from the congregation in order to maximize capacity. There is a limited overflow capacity of 8 seats in the common room. Walk-ins will be permitted if space is available, but they will need to provide contact information in the event contact tracing is necessary. You will receive more information about reserving seats soon.

We all look forward to raising our voices in song, but for the time being we will need to keep our masks on while singing (except for the choir). There will be some other adjustments, as well. The sign of peace will be by wave. (Hugs before and after liturgy are up to you, but please respect everyone’s comfort level.)

Communion will be in the form of bread only, and only in the hand, given by a single presider or eucharistic minister who will visibly wash their hands before the consecration. We will process to the altar slightly differently and stand in designated spots around the sanctuary to receive Communion.

There will be hand sanitizer at the door. Since touch has now been determined by the CDC to have a low risk of transmission, we will be using our regular hymnals and paper materials as needed. Name tags will be offered but will be optional as always. The collection will be taken using our regular baskets, as before.

During the warm weather months, we will hold the social in the courtyard. We do not need to wear masks there, and we can serve both food and drink outside. If we move into the common room because of bad weather, we must continue to wear masks, and drinks only may be served.

We know from our survey that we are a heavily vaccinated community, at or very close to 100%. We know that infection rates in the city and region have fallen to very low levels. So far, the vaccines have been shown to be extremely effective against infection and severe illness. Given all that, plus the strong safety measures still in place at St. John’s, we are confident that the environment will be very safe for worship and socializing. Although we do not currently plan to ask anyone for proof of vaccination, we strongly urge anyone who has not yet received a vaccine to do so, for their own protection as well as that of the entire community.

We look forward to seeing you at our Zoom liturgies on June 7 and June 13, and then in person on June 20 at St. John’s (we hope with a Zoom link to the service available also). We will be in touch again soon about reserving seats. Feel free to contact any member of the Steering Community if you have questions or concerns.

We know that many of us are returning to St. John’s with mixed emotions, and have suffered illness, financial difficulties, and the loss of loved ones during the pandemic. We look forward to renewing our ties in person and sustaining one another through the traditions of our faith as we celebrate, grieve, and move forward into our 49th year as a community.

In Dignity,

The Steering Committee of Dignity/New York

Chris Alberti, Larry Caputo, Andrew Jones, Danny Larkin, Tom McLoughlin, James Osbourn, Lewis Speaks-Tanner, and Jeff Stone

title: Easter Day Witness at St. Patrick's Cathedral
body:
A Witness organized by Brendan Fay was held at St. Patrick’s Cathedral on Easter morning. The Witness protested the recent Vatican statement saying that the Catholic Church cannot bless same-sex unions. Icons of out gay priests John McNeill and Mychal Judge, both closely associated with Dignity/New York, and the rainbow banner created for us by rainbow flag creator Gilbert Baker added to the visual impact.

Photo credit Garry Rissman
Rally organizer: Brendan Fay

title: Dignity/New York's Online Sunday Liturgies
body:
Please join us for our online liturgy each Sunday at 6:30 PM (Eastern time) as we gather for worship.   The meeting room will open at 6:00 PM.

title: Participate in the DignityUSA Townhall - Responding to the Responsum
body:
DignityUSA Townhall - Responding to the Responsum

Wednesday March 24th, 8:00pm Eastern, 7:00pm Central, 6:00pm Mountain, 5:00pm Pacific, 2:00pm Hawaii - Aleutian on Zoom.

Last week, the Vatican's Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith issued a responsum, a statement that declared that the Church cannot bless same-sex unions. This statement, which received Pope Francis' approval, came as Bishops in Germany and elsewhere had begun seriously considering allowing priests to bless same-sex couples.

We were saddened and disapointed to hear about this new statement. We launched a response, highlighting that the Vatican's new statement will "exacerbate the pain and anger of LGBTQI Catholics." Since then, DignityUSA leaders have been featured in dozens of national and local news outlets covering the Vatican statement and sharing the response of LGBTQI Catholics

In the week since the Vatican's statement, we've heard from our friends, allies, and community members expressing their sadness, frustration, and disapointment. That's why we're hosting a nationwide DignityUSA Townhall this Wednesday, March 24th at 8:00pm Eastern on Zoom.

At this nationwide gathering you'll hear from DignityUSA leaders about how we're responding, learn about our strategy going forward, and have the opportunity to share your thoughts and feelings. Listen and share with us.

Register https://www.dignityusa.org/civicrm/event/register?cid=0&reset=1&id=115 to receive the Zoom link and join us this Wednesday.

title: Local Media Coverage Over Same Sex Blessing  Ban Vatican Wants to Impose
body:
More than 25 national and local media outlets, including 4 from our area, reached out to Dignity for our reaction to the Vatican statement on same-sex blessings. New York chapter spokesperson Jeff Stone and member Kathleen Kane were quoted in Newsday, Jeff appeared in a story on WCBS TV, and DignityUSA Executive Director Marianne Duddy-Burke was quoted in The New York Times and Gay City News. You can see the full list and find links to all these stories here.

https://www.dignityusa.org/news/dignity-news-responding-vatican-stateme…

title: World AIDS Day 2019 Ending the HIV/AIDS Epidemic: Community by Community
body:
World AIDS Day (December 1) is a time to remember those we've lost to HIV/AIDS, celebrate our successes in saving and improving the lives of people living with HIV, and renew our commitment to ending the HIV epidemic in the United States and around the world.

We will remember those who have died of AIDS and those who are affected by HIV/AIDS at our Sunday evening liturgy at St. John's in the Village.

Please send us the names of those you would like remembered to InMemoriam@dignityny.org

title: Come To The Table announces "Evening Prayer at Home"
body:
Come To The Table: Catholic Worship for All is a liturgy celebrated in over 25 HouseChurch communities and at the LGBT Center on the 3rd Sunday of the month.

Many people use our liturgies for their private prayer and reflection. Our liturgy focuses on the experiences of our community and is meant to draw people into a reflective place where everyone is welcome.

We will pilot “Evening Prayer At Home” beginning this week, Wednesday, November 13, 2019 7:30 PM EDT by phone or online.   Our goal is to create community between our HouseChurch members.  

Email ComeToTheTable@DignityNY.org to register.

Our monthly liturgy can be found on our webpage Come To The Table.   If you would like to receive our monthly liturgy or be added to our announcement email, email us at ComeToTheTable@DignityNY.org

Come To The Table: Catholic Worship for All

Third Sunday of the month 10:30 AM - 12:00 PM

LGBT Center, 208 West 13th Street, NYC

Everyone Is Welcome at the Table.

title: Father Gary 5 years ago
body:
5 Years Ago....

 

Five years ago, on the eve of my 15th year anniversary to the priesthood, I announced on social media the release of the 2nd edition to my book “Hidden Voices, Reflections of a Gay Catholic Priest.” The response to my announcement and book was overwhelming. 

 

 

 

In the past five years, I received hundreds and hundreds of correspondences from people all around the world – all in support of my book.  In addition, I received dozens and dozens of requests to be interviewed for magazines, television, social media and radio.  My story was picked up internationally and I granted interviews in London, Italy, Canada, Argentina, and even Russia to name a few.  There is no way I could have prepared for or predicted, the overwhelming response I received. 

 

The question I often get asked today is, “Was it worth it?”  The answer – YES!  I have said repeatedly over the years that there have been two major moments of clarity in my life.  The first, was the decision to become a priest.  I have never regretted that decisions and believe wholeheartedly that God has called me to the priesthood.  The second, was my decision to come out – publicly, and to speak my truth.  Far too many teenagers contemplate and commit suicide because they are struggling with their sexual identity.  One of the biggest obstacle to LGBT acceptance in our society today is religion.  So – YES!  It has been worth it. 

 

Today, I live and work as a psychotherapist in NYC while promoting the dignity and equality of all people regardless of who they love.  Furthermore, I have joined a Catholic Community, Dignity/New York, who like myself, is committed to LGBTQI equality.

title: “TAKING STOCK TODAY,” Part Two of preparations for DignityUSA’s Jubilee 50th anniversary in 2019
body:
Join us on Sunday, June 10, 4:00 to 5:30 PM at St. John’s in the Village for "Taking Stock Today" discussion followed by sandwiches, salads, soft drinks, and dessert before liturgy. 

The first part of our Jubilee discussions, “Recalling Our Roots,” was a great success last November.  About 30 of us gathered to hear the recollections of some of our earliest members about Dignity/New York’s beginnings and feel the energy that started our movement.  Discussion between the generations continued at a lively early dinner before liturgy.

 

On June 10, we will hold Part Two of the Jubilee discussions and look at where we are today.  The DignityUSA Board has suggested a few questions to help focus the conversation:

 

1.       How is DignityUSA different today than it was in the past? How are your local chapter and community different?  How are YOU different? 

2.       Considering the passion and conviction that fueled our growth, how well is our “engine” running, (nationally and locally) in terms of inspiring passion, involvement, change, etc. – in service to our mission today? 

3.       Is the mission and purpose of Dignity still relevant today?  If not, why not?  If it is, what key challenges and opportunities do you see ahead?  

4.       With the benefit of hindsight, how has Dignity changed lives for the better, locally and nationally?  Changed the Catholic community?  Impacted the LGBTQ social justice movement? 

5.  What clues might the Spirit be giving us?   

 

Please join us to offer your vital perspective on where Dignity is today as a movement, what challenges we face, and where we are going in the future.

 

RSVP to Jubilee50 at  dignityny.org by June 3rd.

title: Prayer for Transgender Justice
body: Loving Creator, Let the rain come and wash away the ancient grudges, the bitter hatreds held and nurtured over generations. Let the rain wash away the memory of the heart, and neglect. Then Oh God, let the sun come out and fill the sky with beautiful rainbows. Let the warmth of the Sun heal us wherever we are broken. Let It burn away the fog so that each of us sees each other clearly. So that we can move beyond labels, beyond accents, gender, sexual orientation, or skin color. Let the warmth and brightness of the sun melt our selfishness. So that we can share the joy and sorrow of our neighbors. And let the light of the sun be so strong that we will see all people as our neighbors. Let the Earth, nourished by rain, bring forth flowers to surround us with your beauty, and let the mountains teach our hearts to reach upward to heaven. Then, Dear God, grant us comfort, give us peace, and allow us strength to enable us to Stand up, Fight for, and be a Voice for Equality. In Jesus’ name, Amen!    Offered by Rev. Debra J. Hopkins, Black trans woman, minister at Sacred Souls Community Church in Charlotte, NC
